bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
highlights: Early winter conditions exist. Daily avalanche bulletins start November 20.
avalancheSummary: The most likely early season problem you’ll have to deal with involves wind and storm slabs that are poorly bonded to the underlying snow. These are most dangerous during and immediately after a storm and are most commonly found in alpine bowls and in the lee of ridgelines. The danger can last much longer where slabs of this season’s snow overlie old patches of snow from last year, on sit on top of glacial ice. This is because the bond between last year’s snow and this year’s is often quite poor.  Temperatures will typically fluctuate at this time of year, often bouncing above and below zero C. If you get a rapid spell of warming, or worse—rain, immediately after a good dump of snow, there’s a good chance of seeing an avalanche cycle. The consequences of being caught in an avalanche are heightened at this time of year, since trees, stumps and rocks litter runout zones. This is worth keeping in mind, as getting dragged through this kind of nastiness is definitely something to avoid.
snowpackSummary: At this time of year, successive early winter storms lead to a rapid buildup of the snowpack. Expect big changes to the snowpack structure with elevation, with full-on winter conditions in the Alpine and little or no coverage lower in the valleys. Here are some things to look for in the snowpack that might help you identify potential avalanche danger. First, the quality of the slab. If the upper slab feels dense and has a tendency to crack or pull apart as a cohesive element, there’s a good chance conditions are primed for a slab avalanche. Second, try to identify areas where you might be riding over old snow from last year. These pockets often exist near the top of bowls, on the shaded side of steep gullies and under cliffs. Basically, they favour steep, high elevation north facing terrain. These pockets cause problems because the new snow from this year often bonds poorly to the old snow surface. This is particularly a problem where the new snow falls on steep glacial ice. Third, if you identify crusts within the snowpack, these can act as sliding layers, as well as promoting the growth of sugary facets above or below.

problems.comment: Wind slab conditions will develop on lee terrain in exposed areas during storms or when the wind can pick up new snow and blow it around. Seeing wind-drifted pillows, feeling dense surface snow, and experiencing cracks at your skis alert you to this.
Storm slabs are a problem during and immediately following an intense winter storm.

The most prevalent (but possibly not the only) persistent weakness at this time of year will be facets that grow next to a crust, or at the interface between old snow/glacial ice from last season and this year’s new snow.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
highlights: This bulletin is based on limited data. Local variations in conditions are likely to exist. Check out the forecasters blog for further details on interpreting early season bulletins.
avalancheSummary: Some larger avalanches up to size 3.0 have been reported from steep large features on North faces in the alpine that can be seen from the highway corridors. Some smaller avalanches, and a couple of size 2.0 avalanche have been reported from North through East aspects where the wind deposited snow in the lee of terrain features.
snowpackSummary: Surface snow has been wind affected in the alpine and open areas at treeline. Some people are reporting a thin crust on solar exposed aspects that developed late last week, and is now buried by the new storm. The freezing level went up to about 1500 metres during the recent storm. Snow levels taper off to below threshold by about 1200 metres. There is about 60-80 cms of recent storm snow above an early November crust, or series of laminated crusts. Tests have been showing easy to moderate SP (sudden planar) pops on weak facetted crystals at this crust interface, or within the crust sandwich.
weatherForecast: Another warm and wet pulse of weather is forecast for Tuesday night. The freezing level is expected to about 1200 metres during the precipitation, and then lower as cooler drier air moves in from the North. During the day on Wednesday, the freezing level may rise to about 1200 metres briefly before lowering to near valley bottoms overnight and into Thursday morning. The next big system is expected to hit the coast Thursday afternoon. Stay tuned to see how much moisture will be expected to make it into the interior.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Avoid freshly wind loaded features.
  • Be cautious as you transition into wind affected terrain.
• Be aware of the potential for wide propagations.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
highlights: This bulletin is based on limited data. Local variations in conditions are likely to exist. Check out the forecasters blog for further details on interpreting early season bulletins.
avalancheSummary: Some larger avalanches up to size 3.0 have been reported from steep large features on North faces in the alpine that can be seen from the highway corridors. Some smaller avalanches, and a couple of size 2.0 avalanche have been reported from North through East aspects where the wind has deposited snow in the lee of terrain features.
snowpackSummary: The Tuesday night/ Wednesday day storm has added to the load above the thin sun-crust on solar aspects, and also above the early November crust. Recent wind slabs may also be hidden by new snow. The freezing level went up to about 1500 metres during the recent storm. Snow levels taper off to below threshold by about 1200 metres. There is about 60-80 cms of recent storm snow above an early November crust, or series of laminated crusts. Tests have been showing easy to moderate SP (sudden planar) pops on weak facetted crystals at this crust interface, or within the crust sandwich.
weatherForecast: The Wednesday storm is expected to move to the East this evening, but may linger a bit in the North of the region. Thursday should be drier and we may even see some broken skies during the afternoon. The next big Pacific system should hit the coast by Thursday evening. So far it does not look like the interior is going to get more than about 15-20 mm of precipitation. I don't think Saturday will be clear skies, but we should see some breaks and a bit cooler temps.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• The new snow will require several days to settle and stabilize.
  • Use ridges or ribs to avoid pockets of wind loaded snow.
problems.comment: Recent storm snow may take a couple of days to settle and bond to the layers below. Strong winds on Monday may have created wind slabs that have been buried by the new snow. Old wind slabs may have been deposited well below ridges.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Avoid unsupported slopes.
  • Choose well supported terrain without convexities.
problems.comment: A crust from early November may become reactive as an additional load develops from the recent storms. Big alpine features with smooth surfaces like glaciers or last years snow may be capable of producing long fracture propagations.

Recent moderate accumulations and significant winds have added to an ongoing storm/wind slab problem. Wind slabs that formed earlier in the week may also be hidden by new snow although I suspect that they're gaining some strength.  There is about 100 cms of snow above an early November crust, or series of laminated crusts. Tests have been showing easy to moderate SP (sudden planar) pops on weak facetted crystals at this crust interface, or within the crust sandwich.

Snow levels taper off to below threshold by about 1200 metres.
weatherForecast:
Sunday: A few clouds with the possibility of light flurries / Light to moderate northwest winds / Freezing level at 800m

Monday: Mainly sunny / Light to moderate northwest winds / Freezing level at 900m

Tuesday: Mainly sunny / Light to moderate northwest winds / Freezing level at 1200m

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Be cautious as you transition into wind affected terrain.
  • If you are increasing your exposure to avalanche terrain, do it gradually as you gather information.
problems.comment: Moderate accumulations have added to a building storm slab problem that exists as a wind slab in some exposed areas. Although storm slabs should gradually  strengthen over the next few days, an avalanche may trigger deeper persistent weaknesses.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice: • Choose well supported terrain without convexities.
problems.comment: There is a variable faceted crust that exists in the lower snowpack. Watch for triggering on unsupported terrain at higher elevations or within start zones with smooth ground cover (scree fields, glacier headwalls, slopes with snow from last year).

  • Be cautious around freshly wind loaded features.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice: • Choose well supported terrain without convexities.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
confidence: Fair - Timing, track, or intensity of incoming weather is uncertain
avalancheSummary: No new avalanches reported in the region. If you have any observations, you can share them here.
snowpackSummary:
Healthy amounts of snow fell throughout the last week; however, the more recent break in the weather has given the upper snowpack a chance to settle and gain strength. Over the last few days surface hoar may have been forming, and steep solar aspects may have gone through a melt-freeze cycle creating a sun crust. These newly formed surfaces will be something to watch as the next system moves in to the region on Thursday.

Deeper in the snowpack you might find a thin, spotty surface hoar layer between 50 and 85 cm down. As well, the November rain crust now exists over 100cm down in most locations (at treeline and above) and may exist in combination with facets. These layers seem to have been unreactive in recent days, but may have the potential to 'wake-up' with additional loading.

Average snow depths at treeline are approximately 120cm to 150cm.
weatherForecast:
Moderate snowfall is expected to start Wednesday evening and extend throughout the forecast period. Locally heavy accumulations may exist.

Ridgetop winds are forecast to be moderate to strong from the southwest on Thursday trending to strong and southwesterly on Friday and Saturday.

Freezing levels should stay at about 1350m for the entire period.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice: • Use extra caution during periods of heavy loading from new snow and wind.
problems.comment: Forecast wind and snow are likely to form reactive new wind/storm slabs. Watch for triggering below ridgecrests, in gully features and behind terrain features.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice: • Choose well supported terrain without convexities.
problems.comment: Although reactivity has been limited, persistent layers represent a low probability-high consequence scenario. These layers may wake-up with additional loading.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
confidence: Poor - Due to limited field observations
avalancheSummary: A widespread natural avalanche cycle was reported on Saturday, with several avalanches up to size 3. Most of the reported activity appeared to fail on the late November surface hoar layer.
snowpackSummary:
Up to 70 cm of moist storm snow has fallen in the past 3 days. This snowfall was accompanied by generally moderate southerly winds, forming wind slabs in exposed leeward terrain. Below the storm snow may be layer of surface hoar or a thin crust. Observations of this weakness are limited. It would be a good idea to dig down and confirm the existence and sensitivity of this layer.

Deeper in the snowpack you might find a thin, spotty surface hoar layer about 100cm down. As well, the early November rain crust now sits over 120cm down in most locations (at treeline and above) and may exist in combination with facets. These layers seem to have been unreactive in recent days, but may have the potential to 'wake-up' with continued loading and forecast warming. There is also the potential for storm slabs to "step down" creating a very large and destructive avalanche.
weatherForecast:
Synopsis: A broad and persistent trough of low pressure of the coast of BC will maintain a westerly-southwesterly flow with mild and wet conditions for the next few days. A strong frontal system should move across southern BC on Tuesday bringing heavier precipitation and rising freezing levels.

Monday: Light to moderate snowfall – 10-15 cm; the freezing level is around 800-1000 m; winds are light to moderate from the southwest. Tuesday: Heavy snow – 20-35 cm; the freezing level could jump to 1500 m; winds are strong from the southwest. Wednesday: Cloudy with flurries; the freezing level lowers to valley bottom.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Stick to simple terrain and be aware of what is above you at all times.
  • Whumpfing, shooting cracks and recent avalanches are all strong indicators of an unstable snowpack.
problems.comment: Up to 70 cm of dense and moist storm snow has fallen in the past few days. This storm snow may be sitting on a weak layer of surface hoar or a thin crust, and may release naturally or by the weight of a person.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice: • Be aware of thin areas that may propagate to deeper instabilites.
problems.comment: Deeper persistent weak layers could wake up with continued loading and warming, or as a "step down" avalanche from storm slabs.

As the trailing cold front passes through the interior, freezing levels will fall and snow amounts will be in the light-moderate ranges.  Freezing levels will remain near valley bottom for the forecast period.

Wednesday: Snow amounts 5-10 cm, ridgetop winds W 55km/hr, alpine temps near -12.

Thursday: Snow amounts near 10 cm, ridgetop winds SW 35 Km/hr, alpine temps near -11.

Friday: Snow amounts near 10 cm, ridetop winds S 10 km/hr, alpine temps near -13.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Stay off recent wind loaded areas until the slope has had a chance to stabilize.
  • Avoid freshly wind loaded features.
problems.comment: Deep and dense wind slabs are likely in exposed lee slopes and cross-loaded gullies well below ridge crests. Wind slab instabilities are likely, and have been the  cause of recent natural avalanche activity.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Whumpfing, shooting cracks and recent avalanches are all strong indicators of an unstable snowpack.
  • Be aware of the potential for larger avalanches due to the presence of older buried weak layers.
problems.comment: Instabilities may exist within or under the recent storm snow (up to 70cm) and may be triggered naturally or by the weight of a person.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice: • Be aware of thin areas that may propagate to deeper instabilites.
problems.comment: Deep persistent weak layers could wake up with continued loading, or as a "step down" avalanche from storm slabs. Trigger points could be from a shallow, thin or rocky area that could propagate wide and deep, initiating a large destructive avalanche.

confidence: Poor - Due to limited field observations for the entire period
avalancheSummary:
On Tuesday a couple size 3 natural avalanches were reported from the South Columbia Region. These occurred on Northerly aspects above 2000 m, one was noted to have failed on the early November facet/crust interface and running 300-500 m in length.

No new avalanche observations from the North Columbia region, but I suspect that is due to weather, and lack of operations being out. Natural activity is still possible, and rider triggers are likely; especially on wind loaded slopes.
snowpackSummary:
Up to 80 cm of moist storm snow has fallen in the past 4 days. This snowfall was accompanied by generally moderate southerly winds, forming wind slabs in exposed leeward terrain. Below the storm snow may be layer of surface hoar or a thin crust. Observations of this weakness are limited. It would be a good idea to dig down and confirm the existence and sensitivity of this layer.

Deeper in the snowpack you might find a thin, spotty surface hoar layer about 100cm down. As well, the early November rain crust now sits over 130cm down in most locations (at treeline and above) and may exist in combination with facets. These layers have shown isolated reactivity on Tuesday, becoming overloaded with recent storm snow, stepping down to ground and creating large size 3 avalanches.
weatherForecast: Thursday: The region will be under the influence of a westerly zonal flow. This will bring cooler temperatures, mix of sun and cloud and light snow amounts daily. Friday through Saturday: A weak ridge sets up over the coast bringing an even dryer, cooler NW flow. Freezing levels will remain in valley bottoms, alpine temperatures steady -10 falling to -15 on Saturday. The next hit of precipitation is expected Sunday, as a Pacific frontal system moves across the region.

avalancheSummary: Recent reports indicate loose snow avalanches running in steep terrain. A few size 3 avalanches have stepped down to the crust in the south columbia and north Columbia in the past week. These occurred on steep windloaded Northern aspects slopes above 2000 m. No recent avalanches have been reported to step down to the early November crust.
snowpackSummary: Up to 80cm of low density storm snow has been redistributed by the wind in exposed areas. New windslabs will be created on lee slopes and cross loaded areas in the alpine and treeline with the forecasted moderate to strong precipitation and westerly winds. Sluffing (dry loose avalanches) is also to be expected in steep wind sheltered slopes. In the southern portions of the region, you may find a thin yet reactive surface hoar layer about 120-140cm down in open areas between 2200 m and 1500 m. Besides the isolated surface hoar problem, the mid-pack seems well consolidated. The early November rain crust now sits 150-200 cm down in most locations (at treeline and above) and may exist in combination with facets. The facet crust layer has been unreactive in recent days but could wake up in specific areas that are being wind loaded.
weatherForecast: 25-35 cm of snow is expected to fall on the North Columbia until Tuesday accompanied by strong winds from the West. Later Tuesday and Wednesday, a ridge after the system should bring lighter winds and slightly cooler temperatures (-10 C). A weaker system is forecasted for Thursday leaving some light precipitation on the region and stronger winds.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Avoid open lee slopes during periods of heavy loading from new snow, wind.
  • Avoid lengthy exposure to overhead avalanche terrain, as large avalanches may reach runout zones.
problems.comment: Wind slabs are growing in exposed lee slopes and cross-loaded gullies in the alpine and at ridge crests in treeline.

problems.comment: Trigger points for deep weak layers could be from a thin or rocky areas and also where the ground cover is known to be smooth. The probability of triggering this layer is low, however the consequence of doing so is high.

avalancheSummary: Most of the reported activity in the region is limited to small skier controlled soft slabs and sluffing within the most recent storm snow. It's important to note that professionals are still cautious about these lingering persistent slab problems, but the likelihood of triggering is low. Be wary of steep complex terrain with a shallow snowpack, where triggering a persistent weakness is more likely. Glide cracks are also opening up, and the potential for subsequent largely unpredictable full-depth avalanches are a concern.

snowpackSummary:
Slow and subtle change is the name of the game under the current conditions. Surface hoar growth continues with bigger crystals observed at treeline and below (up to 15mm). In protected areas, the surface hoar continues into the alpine but crystal size is significantly smaller and distribution is patchy. Near surface faceting has penetrated the upper snowpack as deep as 30cm, keeping the surface snow soft. The patchy sun from the past few days has left behind a thin, breakable crust on south and west aspects. In some areas (the southern portion of the region) this crust is more widespread to other aspects due to the inversion conditions. These crusts will likely facet out in the next few nights.

Variable winds have built windslabs in many exposed locations at treeline and in the alpine but the faceting process has softened many of these windslabs. Fresh deposits may still be reactive to rider traffic.

The midpack is well settled. The crust/facet combo found deep in the snowpack is still present, but has become dormant.

This weak bonding has resulted in dry loose snow sluffing out of steep terrain. Forecast new snow on top of this weak unconsolidated surface should continue to sluff easily. Steep solar exposed terrain developed a thin sun crust during the recent period of warm air at higher elevations. If the new storm snow develops into a consolidated slab above the weak surface layers and crusts, expect this slab to be easy to trigger by light additional loads. If the new snow is transported into a wind slab, expect those pockets of wind slab to be very reactive; they may fail naturally or be triggered from adjacent terrain.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:

  • Be cautious as you transition into wind affected terrain.
problems.comment: New wind slabs are expected to develop due to forecast new snow and strong winds.

avalancheSummary: A couple small slab avalanches were triggered when skier controlled on E aspect slope. Several natural slab avalanches from 1 to 2.5 in the Roger Pass area.
snowpackSummary: The warm temperatures and solar radiation forecasted for tomorrow could weaken the recent windslabs and persistent slabs, especially those found on steep South facing slopes. If surface snow becomes moist, loose wet avalanches could also take place, and even though small in size, they could become a problem if thrown off your feet in a terrain trap. As a general picture, around 40-60 cm settled storm snow sits above surface hoar, a sun crust (on steep S to SW -facing slopes) and facets. Results on the surface hoar layer vary from sudden planar to resistant planar in the moderate to hard range. It appears to be more reactive in the 1900 to 1500 m. range. The distribution of these weaknesses is patchy, but where they exist, they may be triggered by the warming trend or under with the weight of a person or snowmobile. A strong mid-pack overlies a weak facet/crust layer near the base of the snowpack, which is generally considered inactive.
weatherForecast:
Sunday night and Monday: The ridge of high pressure continues to bring dry conditions, well above normal temperatures.  Inversion with temperatures reaching close to 0 degrees in the alpine, few clouds cover with valley clouds and light to moderate NW winds. Freezing level rising during the day to 1100 m.

Tuesday: The ridge is moving slowly Eastward bringing more mild temperatures, few clouds and valley clouds and lighter winds from the NW. Similar temperatures, with freezing level remaining around 1000 m.

Wednesday: A weak system should reach the region later during the day bringing light precipitation (13 mm), cooler temperatures (-9 C) and Southerly winds.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Cornices become weak with daytime heating, so travel early on exposed slopes.
  • Be aware of the potential for wide propagations due to the presence of hard windslabs.
problems.comment: Solar radiation and warm temperatures could weaken some steep wind loaded slopes. Triggering a windslab could potentially step down to a deeper instability.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Watch for glide cracks and give them a wide berth.
  • Choose well supported terrain without convexities.
problems.comment: A very cautious approach is recommended on steep south-facing slopes and sheltered terrain below treeline with daytime warming and solar radiation possibly weakening the snowpack.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
confidence: Fair - Timing of incoming weather is uncertain on Wednesday
avalancheSummary: Natural loose snow avalanches up to size 2 on solar aspects were reported and a size 1 slab on the same aspect.  2 glide crack releases producing size 2.5 avalanches in the below treeline band on N and NE aspects were also reported.
snowpackSummary: A variety of surfaces await the next snowfall; windslabs in the alpine, facets and surface hoar in specific areas and a suncrust on South facing slopes. The windslabs in the alpine and at treeline are settling and slowly breaking down due to surface facetting. The surface hoar layer below the 40-60 cm of generally well settled snow is not reactive to skier traffic but still produces some sudden planar shears in isolated locations mainly on S aspects below 1800 m.  A strong mid-pack overlies a weak facet/crust layer near the base of the snowpack, which is now considered inactive.
weatherForecast:
Monday night and Tuesday: Another day with the upper ridge pattern. Few high clouds with valley clouds above the main valleys, strong Westerlies becoming moderate, the inversion will start to erode and freezing levels also starting to drop.

Wednesday: A system coming from the Pacific will begin to affect the region bringing moderate precipitation, cooler temperatures and lowering freezing level to the surface, with moderate SW winds.

Thursday: Lingering precipitation from the system with moderate to strong W winds. Temperatures staying cool.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Cornices become weak with daytime heating, so travel early on exposed slopes.
  • Avoid exposure to terrain traps where the consequences of a small avalanche could be serious.
problems.comment: Solar radiation and mild temperatures could weaken some steep S facing slopes and possibly triggering loose wet avalanches.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Watch for glide cracks and give them a wide berth.
  • Avoid open slopes and convex rolls at and below treeline where buried surface hoar may be preserved.
problems.comment: A cautious approach is recommended on steep S slopes and sheltered terrain below treeline.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
highlights: Danger ratings are based on snowfall starting early Wednesday. If it starts later, they would be one step too high for Wednesday.
confidence: Fair - Timing of incoming weather is uncertain on Wednesday
avalancheSummary: Some snowballing and loose avalanches on S facing slopes was reported.
snowpackSummary: Storm snow accompanied by strong SW-W winds will create loose snow concern in sheltered areas and new wind slabs in the alpine and at treeline on lee slopes. These new layers will most likely be touchy for a certain time and could also put on the needed load to awake the deeper instabilities that have been unreactive to skier traffic lately. The new snow will be sitting on a variety of surfaces; sun crust on S facing slopes, surface hoar layer mostly found in shaded-sheltered areas below treeline, facets and old windslabs that were breaking down. The early January surface hoar layer found under the top 50-70 cm, which has been unreactive to skier traffic but still producing sudden planar shears especially under the elevation of 1500 m. in sheltered areas, could become more reactive with this added load. Under these concerning layers, a strong mid-pack overlies a weak facet/crust layer near the base of the snowpack, which is now considered inactive.
weatherForecast:
Tuesday night and Wednesday: The frontal system is pushing its way into the interior and precipitation should start around Wednesday morning. 10 to 15 mm (possibly more in some areas) is expected to fall during the day with moderate to strong winds from the SW in the alpine. Freezing levels will lower to valley bottom and the inversion will disappear.

Thursday: A break before the next system. Expecting some clearing, winds tapering off staying from the same direction, temperatures also staying cool and freezing level to valley bottom.

Friday: Expecting light precipitation and moderate SW winds.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Be extra cautious in avalanche terrain during periods of heavy loading from new snow and wind.
  • Avoid areas where dry loose avalanches activity may have severe consequences.
problems.comment: Storm snow might not bond to a variety of surfaces. New windslabs will form as the day goes on lee side of the forecasted strong SW-W winds in alpine and at treeline.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Avoid open slopes and convex rolls at and below treeline where buried surface hoar may be preserved.
  • Watch for glide cracks, give them a wide berth.
problems.comment: The load from the storm snow could awaken the early January surface hoar layer.  Distribution is patchy in sheltered areas and has been more reactive on S and SW aspects.

highlights: The drought has ended! Time to change our mindset and make more conservative terrain choices.
confidence: Fair - Intensity of incoming weather is uncertain
avalancheSummary: No recent avalanche was reported.
snowpackSummary: Storm snow falling with strong SW-W winds in the alpine will create new wind slabs in the alpine and at treeline on lee slopes and a loose snow concern in sheltered areas. The new snow will be sitting on a variety of surfaces; sun crust on S facing slopes, surface hoar layer mostly found in shaded-sheltered areas below treeline, facets and old windslabs that were breaking down. We suspect the bond between the new snow and the old surfaces will not be very good and that it could also put on the needed load to awake the deeper instabilities that have been unreactive to skier traffic lately. The early January surface hoar layer found under the top 50-70 cm, which has been unreactive to skier traffic but still producing sudden planar shears especially under the elevation of 1500 m. in sheltered areas, could become more reactive with this added load. Under these concerning layers, a strong mid-pack overlies a weak facet/crust layer near the base of the snowpack, which is now considered inactive.

Temperatures lowering to around -9 C in the alpine and freezing levels at the surface.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
confidence: Poor - Intensity of incoming weather is uncertain on Friday
avalancheSummary: Storm snow was already sluffing easily in steep terrain yesterday. We expect that more of that happened today and also some soft slabs formation probably producing some recent avalanches in the new snow.
snowpackSummary: More snow will add on to the 20 to 30 cm that fell yesterday with moderate winds from the W-SW. New windslabs in the alpine and at treeline under lee ridgetops will grow thicker and their bond to the old surfaces will be weak for a certain time. Soft slabs and loose snow is expected to slide very easily on the January 23th surface hoar layer that is located in shaded-sheltered areas below treeline and also on the buried suncrust found on South facing slopes. This significant new load (over 30-40 mm of water equivalent) might also awake the early January surface hoar weak layer that will be sitting down 80 cm in sheltered areas below treeline. Under these concerning layers, a strong mid-pack overlies a weak facet/crust layer near the base of the snowpack, which is now considered inactive.
weatherForecast:
Thursday night and Friday: Another frontal system is moving towards the region. Light precipitation (moderate over the Western part of the region) is expected to start overnight and go until the afternoon Friday for a total of 10 to 20 mm. in the wettest zones. Winds are expected to be strong from the SW-W in the alpine and temperatures remaining cool (-7 C) and freezing level staying at the surface.

Saturday: Trace to light precipitation amounts, lighter W winds and similar temperatures.

Sunday: Similar unsettled conditions providing trace to light precipitation, cool temperatures with light SW winds.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Stay off recent wind loaded areas until the slope has had a chance to stabilize.
  • The volume of sluffing could knock you over; do not expose yourself to slopes with terrain traps.
problems.comment: Expect to find thick storm slabs on lee ridges of W-SW winds in the alpine and at treeline and softslabs and loose snow in sheltered areas. We suspect that these layers will not to bond well with the old surface.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice: • Avoid open slopes and convex rolls at and below treeline where buried surface hoar may be preserved.
problems.comment: The load from the storm snow could awaken the early January surface hoar layer. Distribution is patchy but has been more reactive below treeline.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
confidence: Fair - Timing, track, or intensity of incoming weather is uncertain on Sunday
avalancheSummary: Natural cycle happened yesterday up to size 2.5 on various aspects but mostly SE which mostly ran on the January 23rd facet/suncrust/surface hoar interface. Several loose and slab avalanches were also skier triggered on the same interface up to size 2 on Easterly aspects.  It is interesting to note that a couple small skier triggered slab avalanche ran on the early January surface hoar layer in the Cariboo region, in an area very close to the North Columbia North border which could suggest that it could be more reactive in that area.
snowpackSummary: Around 40 cm of snow fell with the last 2 systems with light to moderate S-SW winds in the alpine and with relatively warm temperatures at low elevations.  Storm slabs are found at all elevations. In the alpine, it is expected that the bond between these slabs and the underlying surface will improve, however they could also gain propagation potential with the continuing settlement. In other words, they could become harder to trigger, but if triggered, they will generate bigger avalanches. The new snow is also sitting on a couple of weak layers; a suncrust on S facing slopes and on a surface hoar layer mostly found below treeline. The bond of the new snow with these layer is now weak (look at the avalanche summary section) and it usually takes longer to improve and is harder to predict. It is therefore important to keep monitoring their location and reactivity to ski and snowpack tests. The early January surface hoar layer down 70-90 cm, also in the below treeline band, is becoming less of a concern to professionals. It has been producing a variety of snowpack results (from break to sudden planar) but has not been reactive to skier traffic in a while.
weatherForecast:
Friday night and Saturday: A bit of a precipitation break with moderate winds with strong gusts from the NW friday night. Another unsettled air mass will bring more precipitation on the region on Saturday but no significant amounts. Light W winds gusting moderate in the afternoon and surface freezing level and seasonal temperatures in the alpine (-5 to -10 C).

Sunday: Similar pattern with possibly more precipitation, moderate W winds, cooler temperatures (down to -12 C).

Monday: Arctic front tracking towards the region bringing more light to moderate precipitations and even cooler temperatures.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Avoid areas where sluffing may have severe consequences.
  • Choose well supported terrain without convexities.
problems.comment: Expect to find soft wind slabs on lee ridges of W-SW winds in the alpine and treeline. Storm slabs are also present in sheltered areas at treeline and on all aspects below treeline.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice: • Avoid open slopes and convex rolls at and below treeline where buried surface hoar may be preserved.
problems.comment: The early January surface hoar layer which is located mostly below treeline under around 80 cm of snow, has started to be reactive again in the Cariboo region in an area located near the boundary of the North Columbia region.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
confidence: Fair - Timing, track, or intensity of incoming weather is uncertain
avalancheSummary: A natural avalanche cycle was reported in the south part of the region Friday, likely connected to stronger winds along with the new snow. Avalanches were generally up to size 2.5 with a few size 3. Loose snow slides and soft slabs are running quite far and fast on the sugary facets the storm snow covers. Most reports were for small avalanches (to size 1.5) from steep terrain.
snowpackSummary: Storm snow accumulations over the past few days are generally around 40 to 50 cm. This snow remained quite powdery & uncohesive on Friday but is starting to settle into a soft slab. That suggests the snowpack is gaining strength in most terrain, however it could change the avalanche character from relatively harmless loose sluffs to more dangers slab avalanches. The new snow covers a crust on steep S aspects and a patchy surface hoar layer on shady sheltered slopes at treeline and below. The early January surface hoar layer is down 70-90 cm. In the southern Monashees a freezing rain crust was reported on the surface Friday.
weatherForecast:
Next active system (aka storm) is not expected until Monday and is likely to arrive with lots of wind. Tuesday may be cold and dry (if you're under the arctic air) or warmer with more snow (if you're south of the arctic front).

Overnight & Sunday: WIND  West moderate to strong, TEMPERATURE around -10 C near treeline with freezing level to 600m possible, PRECIPITATION less than 10 cm of new snow possible.

Monday: WIND NW moderate to strong, PRECIP 20 to 25 cm, TEMP -5 C but freezing level could climb again to 700m ahead of the cold front

Tuesday: colder with -15 near treeline and below freezing at all elevations, light wind, and another 5 - 10 cm of snow

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Whumpfing, shooting cracks and recent avalanches are all strong indicators of an unstable snowpack.
  • Stay off recent wind loaded areas until the slope has had a chance to stabilize.
  • Highmark or enter your line well below ridge crests to avoid wind loaded pillows.
  • Dig down to find and test weak layers before committing to south facing slopes or steep open glades .
problems.comment: Storm snow is settling & improving most places, but I think will be increasingly touchy where it hides surface hoar or a crust. Pockets of windslab exist behind ridges and ribs where the snow is protected from a S or W wind. Watch the fat pillows

The early January surface hoar layer which is located below treeline under around 80 cm of snow, has started to be reactive again in the Cariboo region in an area located near the boundary of the North Columbia region.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
highlights: The region will likely see more snow in the north than the south. Watch for locally high accumulations, which might elevate the avalanche danger.
confidence: Fair - Intensity of incoming weather is uncertain
avalancheSummary: Sluffing of new snow in steep terrain was observed on Saturday. Small slabs could be ski-cut on exposed lee slopes near ridge line.
snowpackSummary: Around 40-50 cm recent new snow has settled into a 20-30 cm soft slab overlying a weak layer comprising of facets at higher elevations, surface hoar on shady slopes, and a sun crust on solar aspects. The recent new snow sitting above this interface has been slowly consolidating from fresh powder into a more cohesive slab. As this process continues, the avalanche character will change from relatively harmless loose sluffs to more dangerous slab avalanches. A mid-pack surface hoar layer buried in early January is down 70-90 cm. While this layer is still on the radar of professional observers, with most likely trigger points being on steep rolls at treeline and below, the last avalanche reported on this layer from this region was on 20th January (a size 2 avalanche on steep east-facing gladed terrain). In the southern Monashees a freezing rain crust was reported on the surface Friday.
weatherForecast:
Synopsis: Northwesterly flow will bring a series of moderate or locally heavy pulses of precipitation to the region through the forecast period.

Monday: Light snowfall, around 5cm, possibly more in the north of the region. Treeline temperatures around -9C. Light westerly winds.

Tuesday: Generally light snowfall, but northern areas may see up to 15 cm new snow. Temperatures rising to around -5C at treeline elevations. Northwesterly winds, gusting to 50km/h at ridgetop.

Wednesday: Light snowfall, up to 5cm. Treeline temperatures around 0C. Strong northwesterly winds, gusting to 70km/h at ridgetop.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Whumpfing, shooting cracks and recent avalanches are all strong indicators of an unstable snowpack.
  • Avoid freshly wind loaded features.
  • Highmark or enter your line well below ridge crests to avoid wind loaded pillows.
  • Dig down to find and test weak layers before committing to a line.
problems.comment: Recent storm snow has settled into a soft slab in many areas and will become increasingly touchy where it overlies surface hoar or a crust. Windslab exists behind ridges and ribs where the snow is protected from a S or W wind. Watch the fat pillows.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Whumpfing is direct evidence of a buried instability.
  • Dig down to find and test weak layers before committing to a steep line in the glades below treeline.
problems.comment: Two surface hoar layers lie buried under the surface, one approximately 40cm down and the other approximately 80cm down. The upper one is more widespread and touchy compared with the lower one.

confidence: Fair - Timing or intensity of solar radiation is uncertain on Saturday
avalancheSummary: Natural slab avalanches up to size 2.5 were reported from the Selkirks. Explosive control in the monashees resulted in a size 3.0 slab avalanche that was about 60 cms deep and ran full path. Sluffing continues to be reported from steep terrain up to size 1.5
snowpackSummary: There is about 50-70 cms of recent storm snow above the variable surfaces that were left on January 23rd at the end of the snow drought. Reports are mixed regarding how well the storm snow is adhering to these old surfaces. The surface hoar layer may be found in some locations, more likely below treeline where it was sheltered from the wind. Sun crusts that formed before the 23rd have not been reported to be very reactive, but that may change when the temperatures warm up on the weekend. The wind has started to transport snow into soft wind slabs in the alpine that are reactive to light additional loads.
weatherForecast:
Overnight and Thursday: The Northwest flow is expected to continue to push the cold arctic air to the East. Northwest winds moderate overnight becoming moderate to strong during the day. No precipitation is expected tonight, and light snow falls of 5-8 cms are expected on Thursday. Alpine temperatures gradually warming on Thursday and freezing levels rising to about 1100 metres.

Friday: No precipitation is expected as a high pressure system in the South influences most of the interior mountain ranges. Expect high cloud or broken skies. Freezing level at about 900 metres.

Saturday: High pressure should continue to influence. No precipitation expected, and freezing level at about 1000 metres.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:

  • Be cautious as you transition into wind affected terrain.
problems.comment: New wind slabs are developing in the alpine and at treeline due to moderate to strong Northwest winds. There is a lot of loose snow available for transport.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
confidence: Fair - Due to variable snowpack conditions for the entire period
avalancheSummary: Natural and skier triggered avalanches continued on Friday. As the storm slab settles, the size of the avalanches has increased to average about size 2.0. Most of these avalanches were in the 30-40 cms deep range, however the fractures are beginning to propagate up to about 200 metres wide. Some areas also reported a thin layer of new snow that was releasing naturally, but without much volume.
snowpackSummary: The wind slabs continue to develop and stiffen as the Northwest winds continue to load and transport snow. The storm slab is settling and becoming more cohesive due to warming temperatures. The weak layer that is buried down about 50-70 cms continues to be reactive. Expect new wind slab to develop with the next pulse of moisture.
weatherForecast:
Overnight and Sunday: Cloudy with light Westerly winds overnight becoming strong Westerly in the afternoon. No precipitation overnight, 5-10 cms Sunday afternoon. Freezing level dropping to valley bottom overnight and up to about 1000 metres during the day.

Monday: Alpine temperatures -6.0 with gusty West winds and light flurries.

Tuesday: Winds shifting to South as the next pulse of moisture brings 5-10 cms of snow to elevations above 1000 metres.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Be cautious as you transition into wind affected terrain.
  • Use ridges or ribs to avoid pockets of wind loaded snow.
problems.comment: New wind slabs are developing in the alpine and at treeline due to moderate to strong Northwest winds. There is a lot of loose snow available for transport.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Be aware of the potential for large, deep avalanches due to the presence of buried surface hoar.
  • Avoid open slopes and convex rolls at and below treeline where buried surface hoar may be preserved.
problems.comment: Recent storm snow is sitting above sun crusts, wind slabs, and other hard surfaces that were left after the dry period of mid-January. There may be a weak layer of facets or surface hoar between the old sliding surface and the recent storm snow.

Wednesday:Light to moderate Southwest winds with alpine temperatures dropping to -10.0

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
highlights: If your receive less then 20 cm of new snow in your local riding area, consider the Danger Ratings to be one step to high on Tuesday.
confidence: Fair - Forecast snowfall amounts are uncertain
avalancheSummary: Several natural slab avalanches up to size 2.5 continue through the region. These mostly ran within storm snow instabilities on wind loaded aspects.
snowpackSummary:
The wind slabs continue to develop and stiffen on lee slopes (N-SE) and behind terrain features like ridglines and ribs. Switching winds out of the SouthWest will continue to load and transport new snow. The storm slab has been settling and becoming more cohesive due to previous warming temperatures. Forecast snow will add to the recent storm slab and will likely continue to be reactive on the weak interface that is buried down about 50-70 cms.

The mid-pack is generally well settled and strong. Snowpack depths at treeline are near 220 cm.
weatherForecast:
Tuesday: The trailing cold front has brought temperatures back down to seasonal norms. The next well developed system brings light-moderate (7-15 cm) snow amounts with localized heavy amounts to some SW facing slopes. Ridgetop winds will blow strong from the West and alpine temperatures will be near -8. Freezing levels will hover around 1200 m.

Wednesday: Upper disturbances embedded in the SW flow will bring continued stormy conditions. Snow amounts 10-20 cm throughout the day, tapering off overnight. Ridgetop winds will continue to be strong from the West. Alpine temperatures near -10 and freezing levels around 1000 m.

Thursday: Weak unsettled conditions will prevail with no significant precipitation. Ridgetop winds will blow light from the South. Alpine temperatures near -8 and freezing levels will stay near 800 m in the afternoon then falling overnight.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Whumpfing, shooting cracks and recent avalanches are all strong indicators of an unstable snowpack.
  • Avoid freshly wind loaded features.
problems.comment: Old wind slabs continue to be reactive to natural triggers and rider triggers. With forecast snow and strong West winds, new wind slabs are expected to develop. Lee aspects and behind terrain features are areas of concern.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Avoid open slopes and convex rolls at and below treeline where buried surface hoar may be preserved.
  • Whumpfing is direct evidence of a buried instability.
  • Carefully evaluate big terrain features by digging and testing on adjacent, safe slopes.
problems.comment: 50-70 cm slab is sitting on a variety of old surfaces that were left after the dry period of mid-January. There may be a weak layer of facets or surface hoar between the old sliding surface and the recent storm snow will add load to these interfaces.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
confidence: Fair - Forecast snowfall amounts are uncertain
avalancheSummary: Natural slab avalanches up to size 2, and loose avalanches up to size 1.5 continue through the region. Rider triggered slab avalanches up to size 1.5 persist, running on buried surface hoar and crust interfaces on most aspects around 15-2000 m.
snowpackSummary:
The wind slabs continue to develop and stiffen on lee slopes (N-SE) and behind terrain features like ridglines and ribs. Switching winds out of the West will continue to load and transport new snow. New storm snow (up to 15 cm) is sitting on surface hoar that formed in early February and is reactive. The older storm slab has been settling and becoming more cohesive due to previous warming temperatures. However, it continues to be reactive to rider triggers over a weakness that is buried down about 50-70 cms.

The mid-pack is generally well settled and strong. Snowpack depths at treeline are near 220 cm.
weatherForecast:
Wednesday: Today the region sits under a weakening zonal flow maintaining moderate-strong ridgetop winds from the West. An upper disturbance embedded in the flow will bring snow amounts up to10 cm. Treeline temperatures steady -4 and freezing levels 1100 m falling to 700 m overnight.

Thursday: Unsettled conditions continue, bringing light snow accumulations. Ridgetop winds will switch and blow from the SW. Treeline temperatures near -3 and freezing levels hovering around 1000 m, falling to valley bottom overnight.

Friday: Outlook shows surface and upper ridge building, bringing dryer conditions and valley cloud. Treeline temperatures near -7 with freezing levels hovering around 700 m. Ridgetop winds blowing moderate from the NW.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Avoid freshly wind loaded features.
  • Whumpfing, shooting cracks and recent avalanches are all strong indicators of an unstable snowpack.
  • Avoid traveling on or near terrain traps where sluffing may have severe consequences.
problems.comment: With forecast snow and strong West winds, new wind slabs are expected to develop and could be reactive. Lee aspects and behind terrain features are areas of concern. Watch for loose dry sluffing, from steep terrain and over convex rolls.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Avoid open slopes and convex rolls at and below treeline where buried surface hoar may be preserved.
  • Dig down to find and test weak layers before dropping into your line.
problems.comment: 50-70 cm slab is sitting on a variety of old surfaces that were left after the dry period of mid-January. There may be a weak layer of facets or surface hoar between the old sliding surface and the recent storm snow will add load to these interfaces.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
confidence: Good
avalancheSummary: Natural slab avalanches up to size 2, and loose avalanches up to size 1.5 continue through the region. Rider triggered slab avalanches up to size 1.5 persist, running on buried surface hoar and crust interfaces on most aspects around 15-2000 m.
snowpackSummary:
Up to 25 cm of new snow sits on touchy wind slabs and persistent weak interfaces. Wind slabs continue to develop and stiffen on lee slopes (N-SE) and behind terrain features like ridgelines and ribs.

The new snow sits on a surface hoar layer that developed at the beginning of February (20-35 cm down) and a sun crust that developed on steep Southerly aspects. Deeper down, the persistent slab continues to settle and become more cohesive over another weak interface (surface hoar, crust, facet) buried 50-70 cm down. This interface will likely be reactive under light loads.

The mid-pack is generally well settled and strong. Snowpack depths at treeline are near 220 cm.
weatherForecast:
Thursday: A weak upper trough moves through the region bringing unsettled conditions and light snow accumulations 5-10 cm. Ridgetop winds will light and blowing from the West. Treeline temperatures near -3 and freezing levels around 900 m.

Friday: Ridge of high pressure moves in with residual moisture and cloudy cover bringing only trace snow amounts. Ridgetop winds will switch and blow light from the North. Freezing levels will hold  stationary around 700 m.

Saturday: Ridge continues accompanied by a fast moving and short lived weak disturbance. Trace of snow expected with ridgetop winds blowing moderate from the West. Treeline temperature near -7 and freezing levels around 1000 m falling to valley bottom overnight.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Avoid freshly wind loaded features.
  • Watch for whumpfing, hollow sounds, shooting cracks or recent avalanches.
  • Use ridges or ribs to avoid pockets of wind loaded snow.
problems.comment: New snow and West winds have continued to build wind slabs and could be reactive. Lee aspects and behind terrain features are areas of concern. Watch for loose dry sluffing, from steep terrain and over convex rolls.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Avoid open slopes and convex rolls at and below treeline where buried surface hoar may be preserved.
  • Dig down to find and test weak layers before committing to a line.
problems.comment: 50-70 cm slab is sitting on a variety of old surfaces that were left after the dry period of mid-January. There may be a weak layer of facets or surface hoar between the old sliding surface and the recent storm snow will add load to these interfaces.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
highlights: Weak layers within the upper snowpack have yet to be tested by the effects of the sun. Blue skies and fresh snow may tempt you into steeper and bigger terrain. Maintain a diligent approach to terrain selection to best manage the current conditions.
confidence: Fair - Timing or intensity of solar radiation is uncertain
avalancheSummary:
Several large natural slab avalanches from large bowls and terrain features occurred up to size 3.5. The failing layers were within the new storm snow stepping down to the Jan. 23rd interface. Numerous rider triggered slab avalanches also occurred up to size 2 on a variety of aspects particulary above 1800 m.

Heads up out there! Suspect avalanche activity to continue through the forecast period, additional concerns being solar radiation as a natural trigger.
snowpackSummary:
Up to 35 cm of new snow sits on touchy wind slabs and adds to the persistent slab problem. Weak layers buried below comprise of a surface hoar layer and a sun crust that formed on steep Southerly aspects. These were buried at the beginning of February (20-40 cm down). The slab continues to settle and become more cohesive over a deeper weak interface that was buried January 23rd. This includes surface hoar, crust, and facets buried 50-80 cm down. This interface has been reactive under light loads.

Wind slabs continue to develop and stiffen on lee slopes and behind terrain features like ridgelines and ribs. You may encounter some reverse loading with winds switching from the NW, watch for unsuspecting areas of new wind slab.

The mid-pack is generally well settled and strong. Snowpack depths at treeline are near 220 cm.
weatherForecast:
Friday: A weakening upper trough moves out of the region as a ridge of high pressure makes its way in. The initial changes in the weather pattern will bring only trace amounts of new snow and mostly cloudy skies. By the afternoon broken skies may reveal in the Eastern ranges of the region allowing some sunshine. Ridgetop winds will be light from the NW. Treeline temperatures will be near -7 and freezing levels around 700 m.

Saturday: The ridge of high pressure builds and brings dry conditions with scattered to few clouds allowing some sunny alpine skies. Ridgetop winds will blow light-moderate from the NW. Treeline temperatures near -3 and freezing levels rising to 1100 m.

Sunday: The upper ridge strengthens with continued dryer conditions. Ridgetop winds light from the NW. Treeline temperatures near -5 and freezing levels around 1000 m.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Be aware of the potential for large, deep avalanches due to the presence of buried surface hoar.
  • Good group management is essential to manage current conditions safely.
  • Whumpfing, is direct evidence of a buried instability.
problems.comment: New storm snow adds to the depth 50-80 cm slab that is sitting on a variety of old surfaces comprising of surface hoar, crusts and facets. Persistent slabs continue to be reactive to rider triggers and can be difficult to predict.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Avoid freshly wind loaded features.
  • Use ridges or ribs to avoid pockets of wind loaded snow.
  • Whumpfing, shooting cracks and recent avalanches are all strong indicators of an unstable snowpack.
problems.comment: New snow and winds have continued to build wind slabs and could be reactive. Lee aspects and behind terrain features are areas of concern. Watch for loose dry sluffing, from steep terrain and over convex rolls. Large cornices may threaten slopes.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:

  • Good group management is essential to manage current conditions safely.
problems.comment: New storm snow adds to the depth 50-80 cm slab that is sitting on a variety of old surfaces comprising of surface hoar, crusts and facets. Persistent slabs continue to be reactive to rider triggers and can be difficult to predict.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Use ridges or ribs to avoid pockets of wind loaded snow.
  • Highmark or enter your line well below ridge crests to avoid wind loaded pillows.
  • Stay off recent wind loaded areas until the slope has had a chance to stabilize.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
highlights: Intensity from the sun may weaken the snowpack and avalanche danger could rise rapidly. Be aware of this and keep travel options open to adjust with this change.
confidence: Fair - Timing or intensity of solar radiation is uncertain on Sunday
avalancheSummary:
Natural avalanche activity up to size 2 continues. Most natural avalanches have been slab releases from from large, steeper terrain features near ridgelines. Some natural loose sluffing has occurred from areas with no wind effect.

Rider triggered slab avalanches also persist. Several reports up to size 2 failing on the early February surface hoar/sun crust interface approximately 20-40 cm down. This continues to be a touchy layer, heads up out there and continue to plan your escape routes when dropping into your run.
snowpackSummary:
Up to 35 cm of new snow sits on old wind slabs and adds to the recent storm slab which overlies a surface hoar and a sun crust layer that developed at the beginning of February. This layer continues to be reactive. Deeper down 50-80 cm sit a persistent weak interface that was buried around January 23rd. This persistent slab has been reactive and easily triggered over the past few days, especially from solar aspects and at treeline and below treeline over steeper convex slopes.

Wind slabs continue to develop and stiffen on lee slopes and behind terrain features like ridgelines and ribs. You may encounter some reverse loading with winds switching from the NW, watch for unsuspecting areas of new wind slab.

The mid-pack is generally well settled and strong and the snowpack depths at treeline are near 220 cm. Watch the duration and intensity of the sun in your local riding area; it may weaken the upper snowpack. Cornices loom and threaten slopes below.
weatherForecast:
Sunday: As the ridge shifts to the East, the region will remain under a NW flow which will keep alpine temperatures cooler under a high solar influence. However, some areas may still see high cloud cover through the day. Ridgetop winds will blow Light out of the North. Treeline temperatures near -1 and freezing levels rising to 1500 m.

Monday: The dominating ridge will be to retreat to the South allowing a more zonal flow to set up off the coast. A cold front is embedded in this flow bringing cooler and windier conditions. Ridgetop winds will switch and blow moderate from the West. Treeline temperatures will be near -2 and freezing levels near 1000 m.

Tuesday: A cold front embedded in the zonal flow will move through the region bringing moderate precipitation amounts accompanied by strong winds from the SW. Treeline temperatures will fall to -6 and freezing levels will be near 1200 m.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Use extra caution on open slopes and convex rolls at and below treeline where buried surface hoar may be preserved.
  • Dig down to find and test weak layers before committing to a line.
  • Good group management is essential to manage current conditions safely.
problems.comment: New storm snow adds to the depth 50-80 cm slab that is sitting on a variety of old surfaces comprising of surface hoar, crusts and facets. Persistent slabs continue to be reactive to rider triggers and can be difficult to predict.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Stay off recent wind loaded areas until the slope has had a chance to stabilize.
  • Use ridges or ribs to avoid pockets of wind loaded snow.
problems.comment: New snow and winds have continued to build wind slabs and could be reactive. Lee aspects and behind terrain features are areas of concern. Watch for loose dry sluffing, from steep terrain and over convex rolls. Large cornices may threaten slopes.

avalancheSummary: Several loose snow and slab avalanches up to size 2.5 were reported throughout the weekend. Most slab releases were from large, steeper terrain features near ridgelines. There have also been a few reports of size 1-2 rider triggered avalanches failing on the early February surface hoar/sun crust interface approximately 20-40 cm down. This continues to be a touchy layer, heads up out there and continue to plan your escape routes when dropping into your run.
snowpackSummary:
The snow surface consists of new wind slab in exposed alpine terrain, a sun crust on solar aspects, and surface hoar and/or facets on shady slopes. Below up to 35 cm of settled storms snow sits on a surface hoar and sun crust layer that developed at the beginning of February. This layer continues to be reactive. Deeper down (50-80 cm) sits a persistent weak interface that was buried around January 23rd. This persistent slab has been reactive over the past week, especially from solar aspects and at treeline and below treeline over steeper convex slopes.

The mid-pack is generally well settled and strong and the snowpack depths at treeline are near 220 cm.

Wednesday: Possible flurries early then a mix of sun and cloud. The freezing level drops to 500 m. Winds are light from the northwest.

Thursday: A mix of sun and cloud. The freezing level is near valley bottom. Winds are light from the west.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
highlights: New wind slabs have been reported to be deeper than expected and easy to trigger. New storm slabs are also reported to be easy to trigger and running fast on a combination of crusts and buried surface hoar.
confidence: Fair - Due to variable snowpack conditions for the entire period
avalancheSummary: There was a lot of activity reported from Wednesday. Natural avalanches up to size 2.5 releasing in the new storm snow or from pockets of new wind slab. Skier controlled and accidental avalanches in the storm snow down about 30 cms. Remote triggering of the storm snow or new wind slabs from adjacent terrain. Explosives control also resulted in avalanches up to size 2.5 releasing in the storm snow, and not stepping down to the deeper weak layers.
snowpackSummary: There is a lot of variability in the depth of the new snow slab and the new wind slabs. Areas that received 30-40 cms of new snow have developed thick new wind slabs at higher elevations that may be triggered by light additional loads. The storm slab in these areas has been reported to be reactive to skiers, as it slides easily on a layer of surface hoar that developed just previous to the latest storm. In some areas there is a sun crust that developed during the sunny weather last weekend that is a smooth and fast sliding layer for the new storm slab. Deeper weak layers continue to show planar results in snow profile tests down about 70 cms and also at about 100 cms. These deeper layers are less likely to be triggered by skiers, but cornice falls or other large triggers may step down and result in large avalanches.
weatherForecast:
Overnight and Friday: Some light precipitation is expected over the Northern parts of the region. Strong Northwesterly winds should diminish to moderate Westerly during the day. Alpine temperatures rising up to about -2.0 during the day under mostly clear skies as the freezing level rises to about 1300 metres.

Saturday: Expect 5-10 cms of snow as a trough moves across the interior regions. Winds should be moderate Westerly with strong Northwesterly gusts. Alpine temperatures are expected to cool down to about -7.0 as a cold front associated with the trough moves through the region.

Sunday: Another ridge of high pressure is expected to build over the interior, bringing cooler temperatures and drier conditions.

problems.comment: Wind slabs continue to build on lee slopes and behind terrain features like ridges and ribs. Changing winds may have formed pockets of wind slab in unsuspecting places. Large cornices may threaten slopes.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Be aware of the potential for large, deep avalanches due to the presence of buried surface hoar.
  • Avoid open slopes and convex rolls where buried surface hoar may be preserved.
problems.comment: There are older layers of weak surface hoar and crusts that are buried deeper in the snowpack. These layers are down approximately 60-70 cms and 100 cms, and may be triggered by large additional loads.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
highlights: The last storm was very reactive, and now the new storm is adding to the load above the same weak layer. I suggest conservative goals and a day of watching what happens from safe lines.
confidence: Fair - Forecast snowfall amounts are uncertain on Sunday
avalancheSummary: Skiers controlled avalanches up to size 2.0 on steep wind loaded rolls that released the recent storm slab. There were a few reports of skiers accidentally triggering the storm slab in the afternoon as the slab settled under warm temperatures. There was one report from the North Monashees of a very steep wind loaded start zone that released naturally in the storm snow and resulted in a size 3.0 avalanche. There was also one report of a size 2.0 glide crack release in the Monashees on a South aspect at 1700 metres elevation.
snowpackSummary: New snow is adding to the recent storm slab that is between 15-30 cms across the region. This new load is expected to create another cycle of wind slab releases in the alpine and treeline, and may cause the recent storm slab to become more reactive where it is sitting on the weak surface hoar layer that was buried on February 12th. The recent storm slab has also been reactive on Southerly aspects where a sun crust formed during the period from February 8th-11th. Loading on the recent storm may cause another cycle of natural activity, or an increased sensitivity to human triggers. There are older weak layers that are now buried down around 70-80 cms and also at about 110 cms. These layers have been unlikely to trigger by skiers, but they may still be sensitive to large loads like avalanches in motion or cornice fall.
weatherForecast:
Overnight and Sunday: Snow fall is expected to continue into the night and then taper off by morning. Expect 20-30 cms total at treeline with moderate West winds and strong gusts. A weak ridge should develop behind the storm creating drier conditions with cloudy skies and light North winds. The freezing level should drop down to the valley bottoms tonight and remain there for Sunday.

Monday: The weak ridge is expected to flatten out and let the next trough move inland from the coast. Expect mainly cloudy skies and light precipitation with light Westerly winds and the freezing level rising up to about 1000 metres.

Tuesday: The next weak trough is expected to bring another pulse of precipitation to the region, combined with light West winds and slightly cooler temperatures.

60-100 cm recent storm snow forms the upper layer of the snowpack. Strong southwest winds have redistributed the new snow into deep wind slabs on exposed lee slopes and cross-loaded gully features. A persistent weak layer from February 12 (crust, and/or surface hoar) is now buried between 60-120 cm. It is primed for triggering and has been reacting readily to both natural and human triggers on all aspects and a wide range of elevations. The effect of a large storm on the snowpack, particularly one accompanied by warm temperatures, wind and possibly rain, will be dramatic.

Deeper persistent weak layers from early February and late January continue to show planar failures when moderate to hard forces are applied in snow pack tests. These deeper layers have not been reactive to the weight of a rider, but they could potentially be triggered during the upcoming storm, further increasing the potential size of avalanche events.

confidence: Fair - Forecast snowfall amounts are uncertain on Wednesday
avalancheSummary:
On Sunday a size 3.5 natural slab avalanche was observed in the southwest corner of the region. It occurred on an east aspect at 2300m. Details of its failure plane were limited, although its size suggests a persistent weakness. It's crown was 150-200cm deep and 200m wide, and it ran for 800m. On the same day a skier remotely triggered a size 2 avalanche on a northeast aspect at 2250m which ran on the March 10th interface. In the north of the region a size 3 cornice failure also took place.

Otherwise, a fairly widespread activity occurred on Sunday within the recently wind-loaded storm snow from Saturday night and produced results to size 2.
snowpackSummary:
Light to locally heavy amounts of new snow fell on Saturday night and Sunday and have have been distributed by northerly winds into deeper windslabs in lee terrain. Depending on elevation, these recent accumulations may overlie a thick rain crust. About 1m below the surface is a layer surface hoar or a sun crust buried on March 10th. Natural avalanche activity has become less likely at this interface; however, human triggering is still possible. At lower elevations where last week's heavy rain saturated the snowpack, subsequent cooling has formed crusts and has dramatically strengthened the snow.

Weaknesses lower in the snowpack have become unlikely to trigger.

Widespread cornice development has also taken place, and cornices are reported to be very large and weak.

highlights: Expect conditions to be very aspect dependant. It is Winter on Northerly aspects with dry snow and very large cornices. And it is Spring on Southerly aspects with moist snow above old crusts.
confidence: Fair - Timing or intensity of solar radiation is uncertain on Saturday
avalancheSummary: Natural avalanches, natural cornice falls, and skier controlled avalanches have been reported in both the Selkirks and the Monashees. No avalanches were reported that released below the recent storm snow interface. The one exception was a glide slab avalanche that released down to the ground size 3.0 in the Jordan River drainage.
snowpackSummary: Moist snow may be found on solar aspects up to about 2100 metres. New melt/freeze crusts are developing due to cold clear nights and strong solar radiation during the day. Periods of strong winds in the alpine transported the storm snow into thick pockets of wind slab that may take several days to settle and bond to the old surface. Cornice growth has been reported to be extensive and weakly bonded. Natural cornice falls are a concern, especially if we see periods of strong solar radiation. Monday: The ridge is expected to move Eastwards during the day, but mostly sunny conditions should continue during the day.

avalancheSummary: Natural cornice failures and wet-loose avalanche up to Size 2.5 continue to be reported from throughout the region. This avalanche activity is expected to continue with warm and sunny weather throughout the forecast period.  On Sunday, a skier accidentally triggered a Size 2.0 persistent slab avalanche on a west through southwest facing alpine slope in Glacier National Park, that resulted in one fatality. The avalanche likely failed on surface hoar sitting on a crust that was buried on March 11th, which was relatively shallow in an area with variable snowpack depth.
snowpackSummary: Surface faceting and surface hoar growth has been prevalent on shady slopes and at upper elevations, while the surface snow on sun-exposed slopes and at lower elevations has been subject to daily melt-freeze cycles. The weak layer of buried surface hoar from March 10th is down more than a metre in most places, and is giving variable results in snow profile tests. However, this deep persistent weakness remains a concern because of the potential for very large avalanches particularly with heavy triggers such as cornice falls.

In some places in the alpine and at treeline this new snow may have buried a recently formed layer of surface hoar or facets. New snow combined with wind will have made large cornices even bigger. At lower elevations (below 2000m) rain has made the snow surface wet or moist.

The March 10th surface hoar/crust interface is buried more than 100cm in most places, and is now very difficult to trigger. Although triggering is now unlikely, this deep persistent weakness has the potential for very large avalanches particularly with very heavy triggers such as cornice falls or ice fall. Daytime warming may also trigger wet slabs on solar aspects where the crust is more prevalent.
weatherForecast:
Friday: A low pressure system will move over the interior late Thursday through Friday bringing moderate to locally heavy precipitation. Freezing levels will be around 2000m. Winds moderate from the southwest.

Saturday: Overcast with light to locally heavy precipitation possible. Winds moderate from the southwest. Freezing level at 2000m.

Sunday: A break between off-shore weather systems will bring overcast skies with light amounts of snow and some possible sunny breaks.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Be alert to conditions that change with elevation.
  • Avoid travelling on slopes which are becoming wet due to rain, warm temperatures, or sun.
  • Avoid exposure to terrain traps where the consequences of a small avalanche could be serious.
problems.comment: With little re-freezing overnight, loose wet avalanches will run on solar aspects if there is rain falling or even short periods of intense solar radiation. Wet slab avalanches are also possible.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Be cautious as you transition into wind affected terrain.
  • Use ridges or ribs to avoid pockets of wind loaded snow.
• Give cornices a wide berth when travelling on or below ridges.
problems.comment: New snow combined with wind has made large cornices even bigger.

Initially, the approaching frontal system will spread light-moderate precipitation amounts with rising freezing levels. Towards the end of the forecast period a cooling, drying trend will take place before the big warm-up next week.

Friday: Overcast with light- moderate precipitation amounts. Ridgetop winds will blow moderate from the SW and freezing levels will rise to 1900 m.

Saturday: Overcast with moderate precipitation amounts. Ridetop winds will blow moderate from the NW and freezing levels near 1400 m then falling to valley bottom overnight.

Sunday: Mostly sunny skies with a cooling, drying trend. Freezing levels will rise to 1200 m by the afternoon.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Avoid freshly wind loaded features.
  • Whumpfing, shooting cracks and recent avalanches are all strong indicators of an unstable snowpack.
problems.comment: Forecast snow and strong winds will likely build new wind slabs. Old wind slabs exist on a variety of aspects at treeline and above. Large cornices on ridgelines pose a threat to slopes below.

problems.travelAndTerrainAdvice:
• Suspect slopes are large steep high alpine terrain, practice extra caution.
  • Be aware of thin areas that may propagate to deeper instabilites.
problems.comment: A weak interface buried down about 60-120 cm has been creating surprisingly large avalanches in neighboring regions. Additional loading by snow and wind may bring the slab above this interface closer to its tipping point.

bulletinTitle: Avalanche Forecast - North Columbia - Monashees and Selkirks
highlights:
We are no longer issuing Danger ratings for this region. Professional operators are finished for the season, and observations are very limited.

See the “Forecast Details” tab below and the new Forecasters Blog post for additional information.
avalancheSummary: Spring conditions are just around the corner. Exposure to the sun, warm temperatures, and periods of rain are the most likely factors to influence the avalanche danger. If the temperatures go below freezing overnight, strong crusts should develop that are likely to hold the snowpack together. If the sun shines for a few hours, the crusts may break down quickly and moist surface snow avalanches may start running naturally. Continued warming from more sun, rain, or no overnight freeze, may cause surface avalanches to step down and trigger deeper wet slab avalanches. Prolonged warming may cause very deep releases on weak layers that were deposited early in the season, or on depth hoar that developed during the winter. It is important to monitor the temperature and the freezing levels as they may change rapidly from day to day.
snowpackSummary:
Winter is still in full effect at and above treeline. Winter riding conditions come with winter avalanche problems and now you need to be your own avalanche forecaster. 

Here are a few things to think about:

Until we get into the melt/freeze cycle, most of the avalanche problems are relegated to the upper portion of the snowpack.  Storm slab, wind slabs and cornices remain primary concerns.

There is plenty of snow available for transport up high which has been exposed to significant amounts of wind.  You may find wind slabs further down the slope than you expect this late in the season.

Storm snow falling on crusts often produces a poor bond, at least initially.

The long days and strong late April sun affect snow surprising quickly.  It’s probably a good idea to steer clear of features where dry snow is receiving direct sun, especially for the first time.

Lots of quick pits can help you put together the overall pattern of the zone that you’re recreating in.  If its been awhile since you were in the snow, start small and gain confidence in the snowpack before you get too ambitious.
